headline: Gutfeld: So it's Trump vs. one of these people

utterances.speaker: President Trump
utterances.utterance: I have a very good relationship with Kim Jong un. I know he's sending out certain messages about Christmas presents, and I hope his Christmas present is a beautiful vase. That's what I'd like, a vase.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Kim Jong-un better get him something nice after this week.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Well, if there's one thing we've learned in three years, it's that Trump will always respond. You ask a dumb question, Trump’s going to respond.

utterances.speaker: President Trump
utterances.utterance: You're with CNN, and you're fake news. The fake news, which is you and you.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: [laughs] Impeachment testimony? Trump's going to respond.

utterances.speaker: President Trump
utterances.utterance: I want nothing. I want nothing. I want no quid pro quo.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Storm our embassy in Iraq? Boy, will Trump respond.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: The U.S. military confirming it carried out a strike near Baghdad airport, killing Qassem Soleimani.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: The Defense Department tonight has confirmed that the United States has killed Iranian General Qassem Soleimani.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: A rocket attack on the Baghdad airport kills Iran's most revered military leader.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: "Most revered." Yeah. A U.S. drone took out the guy who helped direct wars in Iraq, Syria, Yemen, and Lebanon, a guy whose efforts led to the deaths of hundreds of Americans in Iraq. He was a bad guy doing really bad things for a really long time. So, is it bad to kill a bad guy?

utterances.speaker: Chuck Schumer
utterances.utterance: No one should be shed any tears for Qassem Soleimani. He was, in fact, responsible for -- he had American blood on his hands. But at the same time, I think the fact, as Ambassador Sherman said, that the consequences of this could be unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: Wendy Sherman
utterances.utterance: Qassem Soleimani is a ruthless, ruthless killer. There is no doubt about that. Nobody weeps that he is gone. But that said, the Obama administration, at least to my knowledge, did not go after him and target him because we understood what the consequences were.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Everything comes with a “but.” Oh, a terrible, terrible guy. Terrible guy, terrible guy. But. But. But. And consequences? Look, Iran already doesn't like us, hasn't liked us for decades. Iran has been not liking us way before Trump was elected president. Hell, it's been not liking us way before the Trump Tower was even built. But taking out a bad guy is bad because Trump.

utterances.speaker: Debbie Schultz
utterances.utterance: What I think is going on here, frankly, is that this action was taken more in President Trump's self-interest rather than our national interest.

utterances.speaker: President Trump
utterances.utterance: Still a charmer. Self-interest. Okay, Trump ran a campaign on avoiding quagmires, and his supporters had their fill with Iraq, Libya, and Syria. So, this action seems the opposite of self-interest. It's a country's interest, our country. If you ask me, Trump took action to stop a war, not start one.

utterances.speaker: President Trump
utterances.utterance: We took action last night to stop a war. We did not take action to start a war.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: See? [laughter] [applause] I love being right. My first prediction of the year is 100 percent on. So he's sending a clear message that Trump means what he says, that it's never a good idea to stake out your army in another country and plan attacks against the U.S. and think that you're going to get away with it. Not while he's president, at least. But thank God the media is focusing on the stuff that matters. Over at CNN, what was their best headline? "President Trump dined on ice cream as news of the air strike broke," [laughs] as if Trump indulging in a sweetened dairy product makes the strike that much worse. [laughter] Not for me, CNN. It actually makes it that much better. I mean -- wouldn't you want your president to be eating ice cream while he eliminates a mass murderer? I do. That's pretty -- I'd say that's pretty cool. Meanwhile, the experts on all the networks say we are one step closer to war, which raises the question, who exactly is an expert on Iran, Iraq or the Middle East in general? Where is their proof of success beyond feverish appearances on cable news shows? No one has ever gotten that region right, ever. And anyone who sees the killing of a murderous general as worse than sending pallets of money to that generous country can be no expert. He can be a moron. Now, one other expert warned that this wasn't just any old killing. True. This wasn't just some ISIS fighter. It was a top general, a powerful leader of an adversarial government. So hurray. I mean, really, isn't the killing of old generals by drone preferable to sending waves of young men and women to their deaths on a battlefield? So maybe this doesn't mean war at all. War is when the old generals send young people to die. Under Trump, we just kill those old generals -- [applause] with -- with -- and this is my favorite part, as you know, he did it with a flying robot. That's progress. [applause] Let's welcome tonight's guests. He's got a heart of gold and will kill you if you think otherwise, retired Green Beret master sergeant, host of Hollywood Weapons on the Outdoor Channel, Terry Schappert. [applause] Someone call the SWAT team because this guy's a riot. Currently starring in the new season of Crank Yankers on Comedy Central, comedian Jim Florentine. [applause] She's pretty, witty, and from the Motor City, host of Sincerely Kat on Fox Nation, Kat Timpf. [applause] And, you can swim in his footprints, my massive sidekick and host of Nuff Said on Fox Nation, Tyrus. [applause] They're not booing him. They're Tyrusing him.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: Yes, as it should be.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes. So, Terry, obviously, you're a military guy. You're a Green Beret, much like me.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: We were in Nam together.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, we were in Nam.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: We'll be at that foxhole. I was pretty --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Nam is actually a Vietnamese restaurant on 49th.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Yes. The dumplings are fantastic.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: They really are.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: They really are.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Nam dumplings?

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Fantastic.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes. Give me your gut response to what -- this week -- to this taking out of Soleimani and the response from the media and whatever.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Stop there because I know you're sick. So here's the thing -- first of all, hey, it's interesting, isn't it, that Terry Schappert gets told to come on this show and then a couple of days before, someone gets killed. I know people.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes.  Terry Schappert: Just kidding. Seriously --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: So you're saying you had this engineered so you could do this as a topic?

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: I might have called some people. I'm joking. I don't mean to make light of this. So if you're in my --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You should.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Well, if you're in my community, it's pretty safe to say that you've probably buried somebody who was killed by him. You know someone who's lost a limb or been catastrophically wounded. And you know a Gold Star family who has been destroyed by this guy. So if you're an American and you can't get behind the death of this dude, two things. One. You suck. But second of all -- second of all, if you can't care about that, you can care about all the people he's killed over there.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, his own country. He's murdered and tortured people. So, this was legal. It was totally justified. And damn, it couldn't have been done much better. And even as we speak right now, the A-listers are on the ground mopping up ancillary targets, collecting intelligence, and taking the fight to this dude. As I said before, Iran effed around and found out. That’s it.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Do you think Iran --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Might I remind you, audience, you never clap louder for a guest than you clap for me? [laughter]

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: By the way, you think he’s joking. He’s not joking.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I thought somebody might have --

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Everybody say goodbye to Terry.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, Terry’s gone.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: It’s been a good run, guys. Good to get to know you.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Can I -- just one more question to you.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Yeah, man, of course.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Do you really think Iran is upset by this? Because their response is weird. It’s muted. It’s not like -- I feel --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: You know, it’s hard to get -- I mean, to some people, there’s a lot -- to some people who know a lot about this, especially people who are actually from there --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: -- like, you know, and so it’s a very interesting place. They have a really, really deep, long cultural heritage, and they’re slaves of this guy. So, what I said before is true, but also, it’s -- be prepared for more danger, because they’re going to try to retaliate. But that’s -- not taking this dude out would be like akin to saying, “I’m not going to take that bully on because he maybe won’t look at me anymore.” This dude has been killing --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Everybody, yes.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I mean, so sometimes the immediate pain has to be put up with for the long-term pain. This could actually -- it’s going to take a while to figure out where this all goes, but, man, killing that dude -- that was the right thing to do.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: What do you think, Jim?

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Well, I first heard the general died, I thought Shaquille O’Neal was in the car. [laughter] Then I realized it was a different general. You know, he’s my favorite basketball player.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You know, what’s sad is I don’t understand the joke.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Dude. Do you need to tell him? Tell him.

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: It’s a commercial that’s on Fox all the time.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Wait, what’s --

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: The General Insurance --

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: The General Insurance Company.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Roll with the general, and something something.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Something --

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: For great low rates you can get online --

utterances.speaker: Multiple Speakers
utterances.utterance: -- go to the general, and save some time.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I don’t know, I think --

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Don’t applause too much, because then I'll be off the show, too. [laughter]

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: It’s -- our list of allies grows thin.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: So --

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Well, I like how Rose McGowan apologized.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes [laughs].

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: You know, she apologized for America.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, to Iran.

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: To Iran.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: “Dear Iran, I am sorry for our country. Please don’t kill us.”

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I wonder if the Iranian officials go, “Is this a U.S. spokeswoman for the White House?” you know, and then they did a Google search on her, and they saw her on the red carpet in a G-string on a date with Marilyn Manson, and they go, “Should we take this seriously? I don't know, I think this is, you know” --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: It’s legit.

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it’s legit.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: It’s legit.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Kat, you’re a libertarian.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I don’t know if this is a violation of libertarianism. I think it’s moving towards a different phase of how we deal with adversaries.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Well, I have concerns about it. So, obviously this was a bad dude. He was a terrorist. He deserved to be killed. Obviously, that’s true. At the same time, I have concerns about it just based on what happened when, you know, we took out, for example, Gaddafi. There were additional problems. But the difference, I think, is that that’s what I always think when something like this happens.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Whereas people on the left, you know, Obama/Hillary did the exact same sort of thing, and they didn’t have an issue then, but they have an issue now because it’s Trump. And I think if Trump wouldn’t have done this, they could have easily turned around and been like, “Oh, look at Trump palling around with this terrorist.” So, no matter what he did, they were going to have a problem. I -- so he deserved to die. I’m concerned about potential implications, because I am a very anti-war person, but I’m consistently so, and I feel like a lot of people are just against it because it’s something that Trump did.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Because Obama did the same thing.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Tyrus, close it out.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: A couple things really quickly, and I’m not -- we know what happened. I’m just going to the responses. I think that’s fair. You said they had a muted response. You have to understand, when they gave -- I believe it was harsh revenge -- they were going like this. [laughter] We’re being harsh revenge [unintelligible].

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: So, there’s not a lot of trash-talking going down, because you’re on camera, and not the ones in front of you.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Also, to that point, Soleimani had been trashing Trump with memes --

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Memes.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- and he killed him for that.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Bet he won’t do that again. [laughter] It just -- it’s hilarious that people were like -- they talk about consequences -- we’ve seen the mainstream media -- every month, something horrible is going to happen.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: And they’re like, “We’re in big trouble now because Iran is going to do something.” Like, if they could do anything, maybe block. And the second thing that just wows me is that the media also has already started their narrative that Trump did this to get out of trouble with impeachment.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Right, yeah.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Last time I checked, he wasn’t in trouble with impeachment. He pretty much -- [applause]

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: That is absolutely [unintelligible].

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: I mean, that’s literally -- Mitch -- Old Man Mitch came out and said [unintelligible]. [laughter]

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: That’s true, that’s true.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It is true.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: So, it’s --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Well --

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: -- [unintelligible].

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- [unintelligible] good A-block. I had the flu. Where am I? Oh, got to sell some stuff. We’ll be right back.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: And now, The Greg Gutfeld Show presents the 2020 “can’t-didates.”

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: As the field narrows, out come the arrows. So, it’s Donald Trump versus one of these people. Could be any one of them at this point. Who are they? So tiny. His head is big. Anyway, it could be Bernie Sanders. He raised over $34 million last quarter. That sounds like a lot, but then again, Trump raised $46 million, and -- [applause] [cheering]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: We are, like, in Vegas. And he did it while he was getting impeached, which means the man can certainly multitask. Joe Biden raised $22 million, not as much as Trump or Bernie, but he’s still leading the polls even though he’s still saying weird stuff, like how he answers an 11-year-old boy’s question in New Hampshire.

utterances.speaker: Joe Biden
utterances.utterance: How old are you?

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: I’m only 11.

utterances.speaker: Joe Biden
utterances.utterance: Oh, you’re a good man. There’s a thing, honey, called -- I shouldn’t call you honey. I guess I’m talking to my grandson. That’s how I talk to him. I apologize. Now, honey, I didn’t want to break up the NRA. A magazine, honey, is not something you open up and read. It’s a thing that holds the bullets. But anyway, so, honey -- I mean, sir --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: What was that all about, Joe?

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: And now, Joe Biden tells a story.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: I had a pocketful of blueberries. I'm serious. I had face jelly one time, said "come on, man. Come on, man." I've been there. You know, we used to sell bags full of nickels for cash in the backyard. If you've been there like I have, you'd know that -- you'd know it. I got a friend named Corn Pop. He knew about my hairy legs, but a guy with hairy legs can't eat syrup. You know that. I'm serious.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That's so true. He could be the nominee or maybe Mayor Pete -- he wants to decriminalize all the drugs, not just pot, but meth, coke, you name it, which makes sense -- if a Democrat becomes president, we're going to need to do a lot of drugs. Meanwhile, what's Mayor Mike Bloomberg promising? To turn the East Room of the White House into an open office floor plan where he says he'd be working, quote, "where a leader should be, with the team," even tweeted what such a floor plan would look like. See, there's -- can you see that? That's small. There it is. There's President Mike sitting in his cubicle. He's so sad. Sharing it with a vice president, maybe? This is pathetic, fist-bumping his chief of staff while the press secretary's over there trying to eat his lunch? [laughter] So that's Bloomberg's big important idea, cubicles? Boy is it stupid. I mean, do you really want to see your president working in a cubicle around other cubicles? You're the president of the United States, not a blogger for TMZ. Freak. Meanwhile, Joe Biden wants us to stop using coal and he's got a big idea to keep coal miners working.

utterances.speaker: Joe Biden
utterances.utterance: Anybody, if you go down 300 to 3,000 feet in a mine, sure can learn how to program, as well. But we don't think of it that way. Anybody who can throw coal into a furnace, can learn how to program, for God's sake.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Sure. Just totally learn how to code and then get a job at Google. Easy peasy. Wish I'd learned to code too. Joe, what was your thinking behind that?

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: And now, Joe Biden tells a story.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: Look, look, look, look, look, look, look. I would consider a Republican running mate -- a guy; I am serious, man. Look. Barack Obama? Barack Obama. 1977. Maya Angelou. Great poet. Text Joe to 3 0 3 0 3 0 3 0. Thirty. Thirty for thirty. Hawaii Five-0. Good show. Come on, man.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, Trump's keeping the economy afloat amid the weirdest impeachment effort ever in dealing with the media. He wants them to have a great year. Look, they're honorable people.

utterances.speaker: Donald Trump
utterances.utterance: I want to thank everybody. I want you to have a great year. Look, you're honorable people; you have to stay honorable. If you're honorable, I'm going to win the election by a lot. If you're not honorable, I'm just going to win the election by a little. So I'd rather have you be honorable, okay? Thank you.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God. That's hilarious. Beat that, Joe.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: And now, Joe Biden tells a story.

utterances.speaker: Joe Biden
utterances.utterance: Look, look, look, look. You want to talk fitness? I'll do more pushups than babies born this year, combined. It's not an exaggeration. Everyone's talking about Cats. I don't see the big deal. I liked it. Darth Vader. Luke Skywalker's dad -- I saw that coming. Come on, man. Come on.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Tom Shillue, baby.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: Hard work from Tom.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Jim, as a comedian, which Democratic candidate do you think could rival Trump? Or is that even possible?

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Probably not. I mean, Bernie, you know, look, Bernie, raised a lot of money, that's good, $34.5 million. I don't -- do you think his staff actually told him about that after his recent heart attack? Because they go "we don't want to give him any big news." You know what I mean? [laughter] You'd think -- almost 35 million, the guy would get a brush or a comb. And still, no. Could someone just give this guy $10, send him down to Walgreen's, just drive him down there? [laughter] Or drop, you know, $46 million. That's -- I figured that out. I did the math. That's like one million for each tweet he sent out this year or one dollar, actually.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: [laughs] That's true. And he's going to send out plenty more. Kat, what do you make of -- who do you want to talk about? Bloomberg and his open office plan or Biden and --

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Biden.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Like, I feel like if I were a coal miner, I'd be really mad.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes.  Kat Timpf: First of all, if I were a coal miner, I'd be dead in like 15 minutes. But I -- like it's, you know, it's just saying, "hey, don't worry. You know, I'm definitely going to take your job. But all you need do is just learn how to do a completely different job."

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: "And then you can have that one." I mean, like, honestly, like -- it's like if it's so easy, why don't you learn to code, Joe?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it's true.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Because I know what would happen if he would learn to code. He'd go enroll in the classes and it'd be three weeks before he realized he was like taking basket weaving the whole time, you know? [laughter] It's really offensive. And he has a lot of nerve to be telling, you know, people their jobs don't matter and they should just start another one when he's managed to stay like rich and famous and influential, despite not even always knowing like where he is. [laughter] [applause]

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: At least coal miners always know where they are. They're in the mine.  Jim Florentine: They banned people from Twitter for using -- remember, "learn to code" -- that was a controversial --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, "learn to code," that was a contro -- and was, people got in trouble for that. Tyrus, what's your assessment of the candidate?

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: After seeing the tape, I think the Democratic Party should run as a team, I think. [laughter] I think they should all just run together.  Jim Florentine: That's awesome.  Tyrus: I think the entire panel and maybe a chimpanzee should run together as a team.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You know what? You know what? It gives me an idea -- that they do that thing from BoJack Horseman. They all get a giant overcoat and pretend they're one person.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: They all climb on each other's shoulders. The most attractive person's head is on the top.  Terry Schappert: And they could switch when they get tired or hot. They can just like rotate out --

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Because this election is going to be bad.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: So instead of being -- going down in history books for the worst representation for the Democratic Party running for president with more stay-at-home votes than actual votes, you clearly say, well, it wasn't just me.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: It was all of us. [laughter] But, mostly, mostly, Bobo the chimp wouldn't stop throwing stuff at the Democratic Party and that's why, like [unintelligible], there it is, right there. That's the team.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Spread the grief around.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Take the first initial from each name. Make one word and be like [sound effect], and then, you know, just go with that.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You know what -- you're kind of explaining and you know this, the wrestling, when it's one guy.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Form the 15 horsemen.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: That's it.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah. So you have the guy in there and each guy comes in, you smack him that way.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: They can bump and feed for the president because that's literally what they're going to do.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Each one of them -- just form a team, that way it can be -- we can all raise money together.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Brilliant. Regarding Mayor Pete, meth is illegal?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Oh, I didn't know that. [laughter]  Tyrus: You know what, I actually --  [cross talk]

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: It should be legal, as long as you're not going to force me to do it. Then we might have a problem.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: By the way, it is -- in a weird way, you are right. It is -- I mean, Ritalin, Adderall, these are all amphetamine drugs. They're all meth -- meth is just somebody who can't get a prescription.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Dude, I was just trying to say a stupid comment for laughs. And you got to do the "oh, actually, you're actually --"  Tyrus: I'll be honest with you, I would be more excited to see a Democratic debate if they all were on meth. I think it would be a lot better. [applause]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I would like to host that debate.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Breaking Bad with the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: If Mayor Pete, you know what I mean? There's going to be good because --.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: This week on [unintelligible] TV.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: What, Jim?  Jim Florentine: No, I'm just saying if Mayor Pete wins, that'll be good because there'll be extra episodes of Intervention.

utterances.speaker: Multiple Speakers
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes.  Jim Florentine: [unintelligible] they'll be popping them out like five a week.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: My favorite episode of Intervention -- the woman addicted to computer screen --

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Allison.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Allison.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Allison. She's better now.  She is better now, but if you can find that episode on YouTube -- holy crap. She would buy cases of computer window -- computer screen cleaner and just [sound effect].

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: What's the big deal?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: All right, I'll shut up. All right, we'll be right back with more stuff.

utterances.speaker: Aishah Hasnie
utterances.utterance: Live from America's News Headquarters, I’m Aishah Hasnie. The White House has formally notified Congress of the U.S. strike that killed Iranian general Qassem Soleimani. Under the War Powers Act, the president must notify lawmakers within 48 hours of any action that sends U.S. forces into armed conflict overseas. That notification was entirely classified and swiftly condemned by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the Speaker saying it raises more questions than it answers. She wants the White House to brief Congress. Meanwhile, President Trump issuing another warning to Iran. He says the U.S. has targeted 52 Iranian sites and was prepared to strike, quote, “very fast and very hard” if Iran retaliates. The 52 sites represent the number of Americans held during the Iranian hostage crisis. I’m Aishah Hasnie. Now back to The Greg Gutfeld Show.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: All right, CNN held their annual New Year’s Eve broadcast, and the host got more loaded than a Wendy’s baked potato.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: Cheers, buddy.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: [laughs] Wow. Okay.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: That one didn’t -- that --

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible] --

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: That was tough.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: I feel like --

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: Don’t lean against this. We’re more worried about --

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: That was -- it’s time to talk about some of the under-reported stories of the year. First, we’ve got to start with this one. Faye Dunaway.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: What is that? Who would drink this?

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: College students.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Now, normally I never watch CNN. I could get the same brain-numbing effect by huffing model glue with the windows closed. But meanwhile, Bill de Blasio, the mayor of this hellish city -- I can’t see that. Can you roll that down? -- went after Domino’s for selling $30 pizzas to the crowd in New York waiting for the ball to drop, tweeting, “Jacking up your prices on people trying to celebrate the holidays? Classy, Domino’s. I’m sorry this corporate chain exploited you. Stick it to them by patronizing one of our fantastic local pizzerias.” Yeah, you’re being exploited when you voluntarily pay for a pizza. He really is as dumb as a block of wood. If Bill hadn’t been asleep -- [applause] If Bill hadn’t been asleep during ECON 101, he’d know prices rise when demand exceeds the supply. Even the rats in New York are desperate for a decent slice.

utterances.speaker: Male Speaker
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: He’s got, like, a six-movie deal at Paramount.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Tyrus, do you like -- I hate New Year’s Eve. Do you -- I hate everything about it. Those guys -- I hate people who act stupid when they drink.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Well, I just feel for people who drink everywhere being shamed like that on CNN. It was deeply, deeply, disturbing. My dream of doing shots has been forever ruined. I’m in therapy now trying to find out why that -- I had to see that. I’m forming a coalition on Instagram to commemorate our pain, all the pain that they’ve caused, shaming people who can actually do a damn shot without overacting. I mean, it wasn’t -- that was -- CNN -- they just can’t get it right. They just don’t know when to quit. And Don Lemon -- “I got a tattoo. I’m on painkillers.” What is going on? You spend the whole year attacking everybody and going after everybody, and then the real you comes out for five minutes, and America hates you. Like, you can’t even be cool. [applause] Usually, some alcohol, some tattoos, and a microphone is a good time. Not with Don Lemon and the other guys. It was --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: I concur with all of this.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I’m just saying --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Alcohol --

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: It’s sad that they -- but all year they have the moral high ground. They’re above everybody. And then you cut the rules off for three seconds; they’re not only doing everything they talk trash about --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: They’re doing it on TV.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: -- they do it poorly. That’s the worst thing. [applause] [cheering]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I will say this, though, Kat. As bad as, like, Don Lemon does New Year’s Eve, it’s not as bad as when he does the news. [laughter] I’d rather have him get wasted and act stupid and show tattoos than actually try to pretend he’s objective.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Sure. [laughter] So, I just -- I’m mad about -- I’m really mad at Bill de Blasio, because, you know, I live in New York. You know, we live in New York. You look around. The taxes are really high. It stinks. You have to watch where you’re walking to make sure you don’t, like, step in human feces or, like, trip over a pile of trash. And he decides to finally take a stand and get impassioned over pizza. Like, it’s like you said, like hey, idiot, it’s called supply and demand. Right? The only thing that I judge Domino’s for is, honestly, not charging more, because this pizza was going specifically to people who were in Times Squares --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: -- on New Year’s Eve on purpose, okay? These are people who had smashed themselves into pens in the cold, wearing diapers for fun. Like -- [laughter]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Should charge a hundred bucks.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: I’m pretty sure --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Charge two hundred.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: We’ve been there. We’ve been there.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: -- a pizza is definitely the least stupid thing any of these people have spent $30 on. [laughter] [applause]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Terry?

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: So, de Blasio -- now, I was born in New York City, so I can say this. Everyone keeps saying how stupid he is. You reelected him, New York City.  [laughter] At some point, it’s got to kind of come back on you.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, but you know what it is? You’re right, but it’s because nobody in -- nobody --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Paid attention.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- in New York votes --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: No, you’re right.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- because they just assume a liberal is going to win.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: I was just getting in a cheap point because I felt like it.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I know. I’m disappointed in that cheap point.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Me too.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: This from the guy who phones it in all the time.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Go, Jim. Last word to you.

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Well, look, de Blasio -- I mean, it would have cost $110 to go a block and a half in an Uber to pick that pizza up, so for $30 is no big deal.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: It’s worth it.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: It’s worth it.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It’s -- why is it that progressives have no understanding of economics and the fact that somebody having a pizza delivered to Times Square -- that’s worth a lot of money to get the poor delivery guy in there. I mean, it’s a -- we -- all of us at one point have been there, having to work.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: And it’s a nightmare. I will never do it again, thank God.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: If Bill de Blasio’s wife was selling those pizzas, he wouldn’t have said a damn thing.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Oh, she only took --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: He’d have taken the money and run.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: She took how much, $800 million?

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: A lot of money.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: No, for that mental health --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Yeah. It’s all gone.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- thing that just disappeared? All right.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Like pizza.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That pisses me off, because the problem with New York is mental illness and drug addiction, it’s not pizzas, and there’s $800 million that went to a program to deal with this, and nothing has happened.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Gone. It’s gone. It’s gone.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: All right. [unintelligible].

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Greg, you need a shower.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: The problem with this story is that everybody across America is like, “We don’t care about New York,” and I don’t blame you. More good stuff after this.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Do you dread what lies ahead, or do things look sunny in 2020? Fortune Magazine, which sadly isn’t a magazine devoted to Wheel of Fortune, Terry, has taken on the awesome task of making some predictions about the year ahead. Some highlights -- they expect turbulence in the world economy, but nothing like the crash of 2008. That’s so easy. They predict Stacey Abrams will be Biden’s running mate if he’s the nominee -- maybe -- or Julian Castro if Elizabeth Warren is the nominee. Boy, that’s boring. They think Quentin Tarantino may finally win a Best Directing Oscar, and he should. And they think that my pain in my foot may be phlebitis.  [laughter] Thanks, Fortune, for including me in your predictions. I, for one, am excited about the twenties. They’ll be just like my actual twenties, but with less drugs and more toupee glue. So, what about our predictions? Is this new decade -- will we stop believing in media hoaxes? Will Terry ever wear normal pants?  [laughter] And will my cat ever learn how to jump?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Kat, would you care to comment? Do you have predictions?

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: You know, I never like to make specific predictions about the future, but I like to look towards the future just assuming general gloom and doom.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I’m surprised by this.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: It works really well for me. I’m serious. Some people -- like, because then you’re not -- if things work out well, you’re like, “Nice.” You’re not disappointed. I don’t understand those people who get out of bed every morning, and they’re like, “Today is going to be a great day.” It’s like if you have that attitude, you spill coffee on yourself, and you’re like, “I thought today was going to be great,” but if you wake up every morning like, “I bet today is going to be the day I get framed for murder, I’m arrested, and I spend the rest of my waking days in prison,” all you’ve got to do is end up at home, and it went better than you expected.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: That’s true. I do that all the time.  [applause] That’s called the pessimistic optimist.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: It’s the Irish optimist, is what it is. That’s what we call it. That’s [unintelligible].

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: I’m counting on handcuffs when I walk out of here.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible] everything have to be about race with you, Terry.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: It is shocking, isn’t it, Greg?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: [laughs] Yes, shocking.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Shocking.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Where do you even buy those pants? Like, 1971 or what?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: He has a time machine.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: I’m predicting --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, what are -- do you have predictions, Terry?

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: -- a couple things. Nothing for Kat. I’m going to lose more hair for sure.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Is that possible?

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Yeah, [laughs] it is. It is. [laughter] You have diarrhea, so you just be quiet, okay?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I have the influenza bee, and I’m here --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: When people say, “I have the stomach flu,” that means they have diarrhea.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes, but I can’t take --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: [unintelligible] --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: -- Imodium, because that would be bad if it’s a bacterial infection.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: I'm not judging you. We all have it sometimes, Greg. It’s okay. I -- [laughter] I'll leave it at that.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: This is -- that’s good. This is the only remedy I have.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: And it works every time. I’m going to take this from you. Jim, do you have any predictions?

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: After that, I don’t know.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I predict I'll be in the ER tonight.

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: With a very shocked surgeon. “I’m impressed. The whole thing. Good God, man.” Jim, save me from myself.

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: Yeah, my prediction is you’ll get the whole thing in.  [laughter] [applause]

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: He gave it to you. He gave it to you. Teed it right up.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You know, if I wasn’t sick, I’d have more control over this show. You’re taking advantage of me.  [laughter]

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: You told us backstage --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Who did I talk to? I haven’t talked to Tyrus. Have I talked to you yet?

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Oh, I’m good. I’m good.  [laughter] Because I just want to take the horn and stab myself in the neck with it right now to get me out of there. You know what? I always look at it -- I’ve always lived my life where I take it one day at a time, and I don’t really -- predictions -- you’re either right, or you’re wrong. You know what I’m saying? Like, oh, “we’re going to have an economic crash or issues.” Yeah, a few of us are. A few of us are going to have some missed-meal cramps this year. Some of us are going to do well. Some of us are going to die. Some people are going to get born. You just hope you’re one -- you know, you get enough good then bad. You just kind of make your way through it. So, my whole thing this year was, like, I’m going to keep it easy for myself. I’m going to eat more apples. So, last year I think I ate, like, 10 apples.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: That’s legitimate cool.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: I’m doing apples. I’m eating apples now.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Legitimate cool.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: I’m eating apples.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Legitimate cool.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: All win for me.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Worst throw ever.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Did you just throw him toilet -- did that just really happen?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, he just threw toilet paper.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: An audience member carries toilet paper.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: We need to go to commercial now, because -- [laughter]

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: We had a feeling. We had a feeling this was going to go off the rails, and I can say with some pride that we’ve helped to get it there.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: [laughs] Yes.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: It’s actually --

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: I’m just saying. You usually get toilet paper after something bad happens. You know what I mean?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You know what this is? This is Fox and Fiends. Back in 190 seconds.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: He took a stand by slapping a lady’s hand. Pope Francis has apologized after hitting a woman’s hand at the Vatican on New Year’s Eve. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Get off of me.  [laughter] It started when she grabbed his hand and yanked him towards her, which is rude. There he goes. I love this. And he clearly didn’t think that was cool, so he swatted her like a giant bug. In his morning address the next day, he confessed to losing his patience with the woman, saying, “Excuse me for the bad example.” And it’s not the first time. Last year, he pulled his hand away -- watch this. This is the best. He -- like, people tried to kiss his hand, and -- [laughter] It’s the best. I can watch this for hours. I -- look at that. It’s amazing. This -- he might be my favorite pope now. Now, apparently -- God, this is so good. [laughs] All right, they wanted to kiss his ring, but he didn’t want to spread germs, which was very considerate of him. Anyway, you don’t have to meet the pope to get the same experience. I’m developing an at-home version.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: All right. I knew that tape would come in handy. Glad I did it in my basement. Terry.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Sir?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: You are a serious, faithful Catholic. Was the Pope correct in slapping her hand or not, and was he right to apologize?

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: If you’re a serious Catholic, you have to admit that you suck every day. That is part of it. Look, I -- and I’m watching that, and it is really funny. It is. But, you know, in a way, it’s probably -- he probably get tired of people grabbing him and doing that kind of stuff.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: But he’s the Pope.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: He is the Pope, so I think that --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Jesus wouldn’t be tired of it.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Jesus accepted that. I think --

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Don’t applaud. I don’t even know what I’m saying.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: I'll make it quick. I think people like me have the -- he’s the Holy Father, and we respect that, but I think the thing with us -- he’s a Latin American pope, and he grew up with the haves and the have-nots, and he’s very social justice-oriented, which I get. But be careful about that, because now you start putting faith in government and not the church, and I think that’s where he steps off. If I had to ask him about -- if I had to have a little word with him, I would say that.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Maybe one day you will.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: Maybe I will.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Then your ass is going to get slapped.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: I will. Just like, “Get out of here, man.”

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I think the Pope, Kat, reminds me of me. That’s exactly how I would react.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: It’s [unintelligible]. It’s really --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: It is.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Is that, like, a height thing?

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: The resemblance is striking.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: No, just --

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: I can’t believe they did the -- they didn’t choose you.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I know [laughs]. I was in the -- I made it to the top five.

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: You were close.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I made it to the top five.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: A true loss.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I had to kill three of them just to get in there.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: Which ended up biting you on the ass at the end, because, yeah, you killed a guy.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I killed a guy.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: What are you going to do?

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: All right, well, I’m on the Pope’s side big-time on this one, okay? I don’t think he should have said sorry. I think he was completely -- I mean, what -- this is an 83-year-old man, and she was ripping his arm out, okay? And then he --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: He could have osteoporosis.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: He tried to take it away, and she kept pulling. What was he supposed to do, just, like, follow her and go for a stroll? You know, like, walk her home? Give up the pope thing, go to her house, and have a meal? I mean, he did not have a choice. This woman was attempting to kidnap him. Look.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: It was a pope-napping.

utterances.speaker: Kat Timpf
utterances.utterance: This was an attempted pope-napping. So, I’m on his side. He shouldn’t have said sorry. Look, she’s not giving up. She’s coming for blood. So, I’m on his side. He shouldn’t have said sorry. And you’ve got a lot of nerve trying to kidnap the Pope, lady.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Tyrus, whose side are you on this one?

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: You know, I heard bad-ass Santa Claus, but bad-ass Pope? This dude is bad, man. He’s mean. Forget the slap. Look at that gangster walk afterward. “Get your hands off me. You know who I am? Don’t touch me.” [laughter] [applause] Watch the takeback. Forget the touch. Watch -- even the thing when he’s pulling his hand back. “I ain’t got time for this.” This dude does not like making public appearances. He’s got things to do. Literally, watch when she grabs right before. He’s going, “Hey, I’m talking to my homeboy. Get off me, you understand? Move, move.” Watch this walk. “Grabbing on me. I’m the Pope.” [laughter] [applause] “Put your hands on me.”

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: All he was missing was, like, Flava Flav. Like, “You see that fool grab me?” That’s all he was missing, was his roll-dog with him for him to be like, “Man, next time someone grabs me, click-clack, you’re going to God quick.”  [laughter]

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Jim?

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: I don’t feel bad for this lady. I mean, I used to get pummeled by no-name nuns in Catholic high school, you know what I mean? You get a slap on the wrist from the Pope? That’s an honor.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: Jim Florentine
utterances.utterance: That’s like a kick in the nuts by Gandhi. [laughter]

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: He’s not wrong.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: I think that’s going to be the title of your memoir.  [laughter] Kicked in the --

utterances.speaker: Terry Schappert
utterances.utterance: He’s not wrong.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: No, he’s not. No, it’s actually -- it’s a great story. “I -- yeah, I got slapped by the Pope.” That’s never happened before in history that we know of.

utterances.speaker: Tyrus
utterances.utterance: No, and the Pope standing over you going, “King Kong ain’t got nothing on me, punk.” Right? Gangster.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: All right, we’ve got more show left, don’t leave. Don’t go to sleep.

utterances.speaker: Greg Gutfeld
utterances.utterance: Out of time. Thanks to Terry Schappert, Jim Florentine, Kat Timpf, Tyrus, our studio audience. I’m Greg Gutfeld. I love you, America.
